thread.title: Two runners plan to keep streak alive in Lakefront Marathon
thread.title_full: Two runners plan to keep streak alive in Lakefront Marathon

title: Two runners plan to keep streak alive in Lakefront Marathon
text:
Two runners plan to keep streak alive in Lakefront Marathon By Gary D'Amato of the Journal Sentinel Oct. 1, 2015 8:28 p.m. (0) Comments Bill Boehm 
Bill Boehm wants to keep running in the Lakefront Marathon for as long as he's able to put one foot in front of the other. 
"Once I stop I'll be an ex-marathoner," Boehm said, "and I don't want to be an ex-anything." 
Boehm, who turned 73 Wednesday, is one of two runners who have crossed the finish line every year the Lakefront Marathon has been held — 34 and counting. 
"The Milwaukee marathon is one thing I don't want to give up because it gives me bragging rights," said Boehm, who lives in Sheboygan Falls. "Ninety-nine percent of the people I hang around with don't run. It's retired people and people who play nine holes of golf in a cart and then have to take a nap." 
The 35th Lakefront Marathon, the Badgerland Striders' signature event, begins at 7:30 a.m. Sunday at Grafton High School. 
A record 3,500 entrants representing 37 states and five foreign countries will work their way east and then south on the relatively flat and scenic 26.2-mile point-to-point course. The first runners are expected to cross the finish line in Veterans Park about 10 a.m. 
Before Boehm became a marathoner, he equated running 26 miles with mountain climbing or bull riding. 
"It was one of the crazy things people did," he said. "Then I met a guy who ran marathons to be a better skier. He said, 'You ought to try it. It's not that bad. If you can run 10 miles you can run 26.' Which is bogus." 
Boehm tried it and liked it. Thirty-five years later, he's still going strong. 
"But it's getting to the point where just getting through it is hard work," he said. "Thirty-five years ago I'd run to beat a certain time. Now I'm just trying to beat my last time. Even the training is getting hard." 
Jim Bahr of New Berlin also has finished every Lakefront Marathon. Duane Tate of Lake Mills has toed the starting line every year but was unable to finish the race in 2012 because of an injury. 
"I thought I would only run until age 70, but I just keep going," said the 72-year-old Bahr. "I didn't plan this (streak). It just happened." 
Bahr has won his age division in the Lakefront Marathon 12 times. 
Asked why he keeps coming back, he said, "It's the people, not just the runners. It's the people offering you refreshments, offering you encouragement. They're probably thinking, 'There goes another crazy person.'" 
Race director Jon Mueller calls Boehm, Bahr and Tate "our machine runners." 
"They're inspiring to me and hopefully to other people," he said. 
There are a couple minor changes to the course because of construction in Bayside. A course map and other race information is available at badgerlandstriders.org . 
"I think we've gained a very good reputation of being a small-sized marathon with world-class amenities," Mueller said. "We've got an incredible pool of talent with the Badgerland Striders. They're passionate and dedicated and they have 35 years of experience doing this. 
"And then the course itself is executed very well, and it's a beautiful course. We have a lot of repeat runners from all around the country and the world." © 2015 , Journal Sentinel Inc. All rights reserved. About Gary D'Amato 
Gary D'Amato covers golf and the Olympic Games and writes about a variety of other sports. He has won numerous writing awards from the Golf Writers Association of America, the Associated Press Sports Editors and the Milwaukee Press Club.
